items.title: mermaid graphs cannot be parsed
items.body:
Hi, I have a problem with HTML files which include a mermaid graph. Background: [mermaid](https://mermaid-js.github.io/mermaid/#/) allows creating diagrams via a programming language. This is then rendered by the browser, as outlined [here](https://mermaid-js.github.io/mermaid/#/usage?id=hosting-mermaid-on-a-web-page). Sample code: ```html
graph LR A --- B B-->C[fa:fa-ban forbidden] B-->D(fa:fa-spinner);
``` which renders to: [![](https://mermaid.ink/img/eyJjb2RlIjoiZ3JhcGggTFJcbiAgICAgIEEgLS0tIEJcbiAgICAgIEItLT5DW2ZhOmZhLWJhbiBmb3JiaWRkZW5dXG4gICAgICBCLS0-)](https://mermaid-js.github.io/docs/mermaid-live-editor-beta/#/edit/eyJjb2RlIjoiZ3JhcGggTFJcbiAgICAgIEEgLS0tIEJcbiAgICAgIEItLT5DW2ZhOmZhLWJhbiBmb3JiaWRkZW5dXG4gICAgICBCLS0-) This is correctly rendered in a browser, but WeasyPrint only displays the raw text and does not render the diagram. Is that something that can be remedied or is it inherently incompatible with WeasyPrint? Thanks! See also: https://github.com/mermaid-js/mermaid

items.title: OSError: cannot load library 'gobject-2.0': error 0x7e.  Additionally, ctypes.util.find_library() did not manage to locate a library called 'gobject-2.0'
items.body:
I installed the package weasyprint according to the instructions Installing weasyprint (Django project). My system: win 10. I have installed gtk3 and all dependencies and it is present in my PATH.

```
# Обработчик для отображения содержимого PDF чека:
@staff_member_required
def order_admin_pdf(request, order_id):
    # Получаем заказ по ID:
    order = get_object_or_404(Order, id=order_id)
    # Передаем объект в функцию render_to через генерацию шаблона pdf.html HTML в виде строки:
    html = render_to_string('shop/orders/order_admin_pdf.html',
                            {'order': order})
    # Создаем объект овтета с типом содержимого application/pdf и заголовком Content-Disposition:
    response = HttpResponse(content_type='application/pdf')
    response['Content-Disposition'] = 'filename=order_{}.pdf"'.format(order.id)
    # Вызов метода weasyprint для получения PDF документа:
    weasyprint.HTML(string=html).write_pdf(response,
                                           stylesheets=[weasyprint.CSS(
                                               settings.STATIC_ROOT + 'css/pdf.css')])
    return response
```
Error:
`OSError: cannot load library 'gobject-2.0': error 0x7e. Additionally, ctypes.util.find_library() did not manage to locate a library called 'gobject-2.0'`

items.title: Image Loading Failure
items.body:
Hi all,

I'm running `weasyprint 51 ` through a Python 3.8/Django 2.2 application, and everything is loading fine, the PDF generated looks great, except for image loading. The images in the document don't load at all, the alt text appears fine, but no image file. The PDF loads the fonts (included as URLs with `{% static '' %}` tags as well) so it's not a `base_url` issue. I thought it might have been a issue communicating with the server, but since the font files load without any issue that can't be it.

Any other ideas as to what would prevent images from loading, or ways to debug the issue?

Thanks

Dear weasyPrint team!

I am looking for a way to get some indication of progress during the weasyPrint conversion. Disclaimer: It does not have to be overly precise.

Idea: Our host-programm could happily read and parse from weasyPrints std::cout special messages like "Stage: 2/3: <html processing> progress: 67% - 13566/20000" or so.

Could you give me a recommendation where you would put such an output in the weasyPrint process?

Thanks a lot in advance!

Johannes

items.title: Non-breaking whitespace ahead of <a> element is ignored
items.body:

In the following example, the first two paragraphs work as expected, but not the third. Here, the non-breaking whitespace ahead of the `` element is ignored. lorem ipsum lorem ipsum lorem ipsum lorem ipsum lorem ipsum lorem ipsum lorem lore Figure 1

lorem ipsum lorem ipsum lorem ipsum lorem ipsum lorem ipsum lorem ipsum lorem lore Figure 1

lorem ipsum lorem ipsum lorem ipsum lorem ipsum lorem ipsum lorem ipsum lorem lore Figure 1

items.title: Potential memory leak / infinite loop scenario
items.body:
So I have a problem which is quite similar to #923 . There is an HTML document that is causing CPU usage to increase to 100% and causes memory usage issues when I call ``.write_pdf`` function on it.

I have actually spent the last few days to create a quasi-minimal HTML document with cleaned data to reproduce the problem and share it here, and this is it:

[leak.txt](https://github.com/Kozea/WeasyPrint/files/4982538/leak.txt)

Some of the css markers in there might not be fully needed to reproduce the problem. I hope you enjoy the images I've included :). The thing which is important to replicate the issue is that those images are of certain sizes (I'm not sure if it's related only to width, or to both width and height of the images).

The problem occurs on an env with latest WeasyPrint installed:

```bash
pip freeze
cairocffi==1.1.0
CairoSVG==2.4.2
cffi==1.14.1
cssselect2==0.3.0
defusedxml==0.6.0
html5lib==1.1
Pillow==7.2.0
pkg-resources==0.0.0
pycparser==2.20
Pyphen==0.9.5
six==1.15.0
tinycss2==1.0.2
WeasyPrint==51
webencodings==0.5.1
```

python version I've tested it on is ``3.6.9``. I have also tested it on python 3.8.4 with the same results (production env is running on that one).

OS is ubuntu 18.04:

```
 uname -a
Linux ubuntu-bionic 4.15.0-112-generic #113-Ubuntu SMP Thu Jul 9 23:41:39 UTC 2020 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```

I have managed to "fix" the problem currently by setting the ``width`` of ``table`` element to ``95%`` instead of ``100%``.

Steps to replicate the problem in python console:
```python
content = """<content from the .txt file attached to this bug report>"""
from weasyprint import HTML
from tempfile import NamedTemporaryFile
html = HTML(string=content, encoding="utf-8")
temp_file = NamedTemporaryFile()
html.write_pdf(target=temp_file)
```

Maybe there's some way of raising an error when an infinite loop of operations is detected (e.g. limiting the number of calls that can be made for certain function) or some other fail-safe mechanism that will not allow memory usage to rise? I understand that this is quite a specific (and pretty weird) edge case, I'm a bit worried that there are more of those around though.

items.title: Nested <thead>
items.body: I have a table with a `` and mostly ordinary rows. Some of the rows are nested tables with their own ``. I would like page breaking and the "repeat header on page break" behavior to work for all these nested tables. If I have valid HTML then the top level table will happily page break and repeat the header however any nested tables don't split on page breaks. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1031306/87563131-ca622a80-c6b6-11ea-969b-b77bc22e56ad.png) I did find a workaround; if I have invalid HTML (I remove the `` around the nested table) then it works but with small unwanted side effects for some elements after the table (obviously!). It's almost like the table page breaking algorithm is only working one level deep (it considers any `` to be unpagebreakable, including ``s that contains my large nested tables). Is there some CSS that I can apply to make the valid HTML work?

items.title: Jinja2 with WeasyPrint is too Slow
items.body:
I am creating a "Resume Builder" website using React and Django. React sends the resume data as json to django, where the pdf is generated. I am using WeasyPrint to generate pdfs and Jinja2 to insert data into the template. Jinja code includes few logical statements (I tried my best to use the least) and it contains little heavy CSS too. The time to generate a single page template is around 14-20 seconds and 20-30 seconds for a two page template. I tried to remove the CSS and kept only the HTML and data, the pdf was generated in a second or two then I removed the data and kept only the HTML and CSS and the pdf was generated in 5-10 seconds. Is there any solution to generate pdf in less than 5 seconds? 

Thank You in advance.

items.title: Random Line Breaks
items.body:
First and foremost: many thanks for this awesome tool! It’s far and away the best html-to-pdf solution I’ve come across 😊 One issue I’m having though is that the pdfs I generate contain random line-breaks from time to time, with seemingly no pattern to this behaviour. For example, a list item generated by [Trix](https://github.com/basecamp/trix) with only text inside (i.e. no additional HTML) will sporadically get broken like this (note the second list item has the exact same content in this case): ```
  • Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.
  • Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.
``` One workaround I’ve found is to set `display: inline-block` on the offending elements (and hacking list styles with `content: "•"` on `li::before`) , which makes the lines break as intended. _But_ doing this also seems to prevent these elements from breaking as intended at the end of a page. The generator no longer splits the element across two pages: So, in short, the issue I have at the moment is that I’m either stuck with random line breaks or unwanted page breaks. I cannot exclude the possibility of this being related to Trix, though it seems unlikely given that the HTML it generates doesn't differ from hard-coded HTML. Has anyone experienced the same problem and, if so, were you able to find a solution?

items.title: Weird linebreak under certain circumstances
items.body:
Weasyprint v51 on Windows

Sorry for the bad title, I didn’t know how to describe this better.

This might not be easily reproduced as it seems to happen extremely rarely and I could only reproduce it with those exact settings, it requires Adobe’s "Myriad Pro" font family.

Essentially even a minuscule change of spacing fixes the problem. So going from `letter-spacing: -0.4px` to `letter-spacing: -0.404px;`, changing the margins, changing the font-size all make the problem disappear.

[testcase.pdf](https://github.com/Kozea/WeasyPrint/files/4675488/testcase.pdf)
[testcase.zip (contains the html)](https://github.com/Kozea/WeasyPrint/files/4675489/testcase.zip)

  3. AC

Page break!

  2. AB
  3. AC
``` This means that adding page breaks before a list item to keep with-next-item doesn't work because you can't restart the list at the correct index.

items.title: Non standard metadata (Brazil Health documents)
items.body:
This is not an issue.  

The Brazil government use some non standard metadata tags in the pdf to validate health documents that are signed with a digital certificate.  

The tags consists of and OID and a description, like this one:  
/2.16.76.1.4.2.2 (Conselho Federal de Medicina)  

To be able to add those tags, I've made a [fork](https://github.com/balliegojr/WeasyPrint/tree/metadata) of the project.  

I'm using the **meta** tag include the information in the html content:
```
<meta name="metadata" content="2.16.76.1.4.2.2 (Conselho Federal de Medicina)" >
```

WeasyPrint will scan to any meta tag with the name **metadata** and add the content to the **info** dictionary, the result will be this:
```
/2.16.76.1.4.2.2 (Conselho Federal de Medicina) 
```

Since this is non standard and specific to Brazil, I didn't want to create a PR to add this to the project. But I wanted to document this in case anyone else need to use it.

[Brazil ITI Reference](https://assinaturadigital.iti.gov.br/duvidas/#1587761771301-8f0416f4-c42c) (in portuguese)

items.body:
Hi,

I try to use weasyprint via python to auto generate a pdf from an html+css web page in a CI job (on gitlab.com).

I succeed in configuring the docker image (alpine), environment and executing without major error the script.
I only got this currently : 
" /usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/weasyprint/fonts.py:229: UserWarning: FontConfig: No fonts configured. Expect ugly output."

But the pdf ouput doen't take the page layout. each block, like title, right column, main columns, are displayed one after the other.

Here is the code : https://gitlab.com/davidchalon/cv/-/tree/16-pdf-rendering-error (working on it)
``` python3
from weasyprint import HTML, CSS
from weasyprint.fonts import FontConfiguration

font_config = FontConfiguration()
HTML(filename='www/cv.html').write_pdf('www/weasyprint.pdf', stylesheets=[CSS(filename='www/assets/css/cv.css')], font_config=font_config)

I'm on a python discord, don't know if there is other source of help. I try to use the examples in the tutorial doc

items.title: circular import in example (gitlab/docker/alpine)
items.body:
Hi i want try waesyprint for a simple html2pdf.

i create a script :
```
#!/usr/bin/env python3

try:
    from weasyprint import HTML
except ImportError as error:
    print('ImportError: ' + str(error))
    exit(1)

HTML(filename='www/cv.html').write_pdf('www/weasyprint.pdf')
```
and i get this error :
` ImportError: cannot import name 'HTML' from partially initialized module 'weasyprint' (most likely due to a circular import) (/builds/davidchalon/cv/weasyprint.py)`

i use it in gitlab.com via CI in a docker alpine image.

```.gitlab-ci.yaml
pdf:
  image: python:alpine
  stage: final
  script:
    - apk add --update make
    - apk add --update python3-dev 
    - apk add --update gcc musl-dev jpeg-dev zlib-dev libffi-dev cairo-dev pango-dev gdk-pixbuf-dev
    - pip3 install weasyprint
    - touch www/cv.html www/cv.en.html www/assets/css/cv.css
    - ./weasyprint.py 
```

items.title: Paragraph followed by ul/ol creates wrong page-breaks

labels.name: CSS question
labels.description: Questions about how to do something with CSS

items.body:
WeasyPrint version 51, Windows When a paragraph is followed by an `ul` or `ol` element, it seems that weasyprint somehow calculates the list as part of the paragraph for the purpose of breaking into a new page. This results in the paragraph breaking early even though there is more than enough space to finish it. Note that the problem happens when the code is `

    ` as well as for `

      ` but not for `

      X
        ` so my personal workaround is to add a zero-width-joiner before the list. I added both files used to create the pdfs, one pdf with debug-borders, and one where only the otherwise invisible `ul` has a blue border. [Gist with test files](https://gist.github.com/Christoph-Wagner/e50219fdd2174338e6ed850e11404875) [localtest.pdf](https://github.com/Kozea/WeasyPrint/files/4090972/localtest.pdf) [localtest-nolines.pdf](https://github.com/Kozea/WeasyPrint/files/4090973/localtest-nolines.pdf)

items.title: unexpected justification
Proxy Support?
items.body: We have a forward proxy to get access to the internet, when I try to load raw html and write to a png it goes through and tries to access all the various URL's which proceed to timeout because proxy settings are not configured. There is mention of the URL fetchers and using a custom one, however the documentation does not provide guidance on how to configure proxy details in one. How can I configure proxy details to get this to work?

items.title: Tables not rendered correctly when they should have moved to next page

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Existing features not working as expected

items.body:
I think i've ran into a bug: when a table does not fit on one page anymore, it is not moved correctly to the next page. Instead, it's height and width is reduced to almost zero, leaving just a small bar. See the PoC below: ```

div: 22cm - Before table

xx
xx
xx

After table

``` Case 1: when the first div is small enough to leave sufficient room for the table, everything renders correctly. (div height = 21cm or lower) Case 2: when the div this so large that it pushes the 'Before table' text to the next page, everything renders correctly (div height = 25 or more). Case 3: when the div's height leave enough room for the 'Before table' text but not for the (entire) table, the table is not rendered correctly. (22cm - 24 cm). I've noticed this behavior in WeasyPrint 43 - 50 (didn't check all intermediary versions though). ![21cm_ok](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/47300287/69899634-86115c80-1369-11ea-8278-dab900e3e1ed.png) ![22cm_nok](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/47300287/69899635-8c073d80-1369-11ea-96f4-88e935fadd39.png) ![24cm_nok](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/47300287/69899637-8f022e00-1369-11ea-99f6-0ab8d164fb2a.png) ![25cm_ok](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/47300287/69899640-91648800-1369-11ea-87ee-43f9ae2e85e2.png)

items.body: Given this markdown: ```js function helloWorld() { return 'Hello, World!'; } ``` Pandoc (2.7.3) produces [this html](https://gist.github.com/roxspring/7f3b1f97b8fbf3eaa680fa6bd5b463cd) which safari renders reasonably as: But when processed through WeasyPrint (48) some weird wrapping occurs: ![png](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/783694/69888128-32a7fb80-12e2-11ea-80b0-057556ce6ead.png) Has anybody else seen this? Is there something odd in the pandoc-supplied CSS and tripping up WeasyPrint?

items.body:
![weasyprint_space_issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45947206/69271284-90319f00-0ba2-11ea-8098-0c9134b8d28a.png) Here's the html: ``` >>> bool('Hello') True

More About the print Function

More About the print Function

  • Taking multiple arguments
      ``` When I started typing in here, I had no idea what ailed it. Turns out changing the code/pre font from Courier_New to SourceCodePro fixed it. So I don't really need an answer or a fix, but maybe it's an issue somewhere else too, that nobody's stumbled across yet.
